text: the Bush administration is proposing to
spend up to seven hundred billion
dollars buying troubled assets that
could be anything from securities backed
by home loans and commercial mortgages
in the actual mortgages themselves it
could include broader things things that
we don't really associate with mortgages
it would be buying these things from
financial institutions the most
important question at the moment is what
price the government will pay for these
securities or these loans this is the
fine balance that Treasury has to strike
the fair prices are very hard to
determine at the moment for a lot of
these assets because it even investors
even sophisticated investors with
complex computer models can't figure out
what some of these mortgages and
mortgage securities are worth the key
here is what happens to home prices and
the economy if you have home prices fall
further that means these mortgage assets
will be worth less because if you have a
foreclosure for instance when you go
back to sell the house in the
marketplace you'll you'll recover less
and if the economy worsens people lose
their jobs people see their wages cut or
their hours cut that will mean that more
people will will become delinquent and
go through the foreclosure process
there's a very fluid dynamic a lot of
the value of these assets depends upon
your assumptions of what's going to
happen to the economy we took a look at
a mortgage portfolio that was
securitized by Bear Stearns the
investment bank that that almost failed
in March and was acquired by JPMorgan
Chase this was a portfolio of about
3,000 loans a little bit less than 3,000
loans it was made to borrowers with good
credit histories and I hundred of the
loans had already been prepaid or gone
through the foreclosure process so we'd
about 2100 loans or so that were left on
the surface is low this pool looks
pretty good but when you look sort of
below the surface there were things that
you should be worried about nearly ten
percent of the loans were either in
foreclosure or the bank had already
taken possession of the property
altogether twenty-three percent were
delinquent by 60 days or more
and or had been in foreclosure so that
sort of suggests wait a minute the
losses are actually going to be a lot
higher going forward oh and by the way
that portfolio has about thirty six
different bonds that are issued against
it so if you early government which bond
are you going to buy what price are
going to pay for for bond a versus
blondie versus bond see that sort of
just highlights the difficulty in
valuing these assets
